I‚Äôll apply my proven progressive policies to create a future of opportunity for every residence in the district and beyond. You can learn more at http://Garamendi.org.
As a State Legislator, Insurance Commissioner, Lieutenat Governor, and Congressman I have learned how to work with all leaders and interest groups in the community.
To the residents of CA-08‚ÄîI seek your vote and I promise that I will do everything in my power to address the many issues that exist in your community.

My love for agriculture will never end. I‚Äôll continue to work on behalf of the residents and communities in these counties that I‚Äôve had the honor to represent for 10 years. I will work to ensure there is a smooth transition to their new Representative.

In Solano, my district office in Fairfield anchors the eastern wing of CA-08, and I‚Äôll happily seek election in Vallejo and Benicia as well. 
¬†
I will miss representing Yolo, Lake, Sacramento, Colusa, Glenn, Sutter, and Yuba Counties. They are all wonderful, hardworking people.
I‚Äôm excited by the opportunity to continue my work in the Contra Costa cities of El Cerrito and Richmond in the west, Pinole, Hercules, Martinez, Antioch, and Pittsburg to the east.

The CA Redistricting Commission has completed its hard work. I‚Äôm thrilled they created CA-08, which includes portions of Solano and Contra Costa Counties. It‚Äôs a district similar to the one I represented in 2009-2010. I‚Äôm honored to announce I will seek re-election in CA-08.

It benefits us all, and we must continue making these investments to make our country stronger, more competitive, and transform the lives of future generations for the better.
Investing in ending child poverty is the morally right thing to do. Investing in our children is the right thing to do. And investing in our families is the right thing to do.

I know some people are talking about the price of this program, but the reality is, allowing child poverty to continue is more expensive for all of us, costing our country $1.1 trillion dollars every year.
Plus, we are on track to cut child poverty in half this year, thanks to the CTC alone.

The Child Tax Credit is the biggest tax cut for the middle class in decades, and it has done so much to keep working families afloat during the pandemic and allow them to reemerge even stronger as we recover.

Stacy and her husband in Kearny, have two young daughters and used the payments to send them back to preschool. The expanded CTC payments give them peace of mind as they face a surge of new COVID cases, potential childcare closures, and quarantines.

When her children's school and daycare closed in 2020, Kelly in Pitman balanced caring for her family and her full-time job. That was impossible, and she was forced to quit her job. The CTC helped her catch up on bills and make ends meet until they can get reliable childcare.

Margarita from Passaic, who struggles to keep the lights on despite working two jobs, used the Child Tax Credit payments to buy a backpack, notebooks, new uniforms and sneakers for her son as he started elementary school earlier this year.

The Child Tax Credit has transformed millions of lives across our country and right here in New Jersey. Over the past year, I‚Äôve heard countless stories about how it's given families an opportunity to get back on their feet, and today I‚Äôm going to share a few of them.

Fed Reserve Chair Powell recently said that broad price increases will ease substantially over the next six months. Financial markets agree.

If they're right, the conditions for a very strong recovery in 2022 are in place. Employment and wages will continue to increase.¬†12/20

While I'm thrilled with this progress, I'm as concerned about rising prices as anyone.

But I do see reasons for encouragement. Oil prices have fallen by more than 20% this past month. We'll keep pushing to address supply chain bottlenecks and labor shortages. 11/20

And because of the monthly child tax credit, we‚Äôve cut child poverty roughly in half. Over 125,000 families in our district alone received monthly payments that lifted over 10,000 of our local children out of poverty. 10/20

Over the first three quarters of 2021, real GDP increased by 7.8% ‚Äî and that‚Äôs adjusted for inflation.

Nearly 6 million Americans who were unemployed at the beginning of the year have found new jobs, with the jobless rate falling from 6.3% in January to 4.2% in November. 8/20

It was reported recently that new jobless claims have hit a 52-year low. 

You read that correctly ‚Äì not 52 weeks, but 52 years. 

The number of initial jobless claims reported was the lowest number since 1969. 7/20

But we‚Äôve made incredible progress.

Over 200 million Americans are now fully vaccinated. Our restaurants, small businesses and schools are back open.¬†

Thanks to measures we took to fight the virus and the American Rescue Plan, our economic recovery is pushing ahead. 6/20
